title: E3d hotend mount for BFB 3D touch

description.text:
This printable mount allows for a E3D hotend to be mounted to the existing BFB 3D touch carriage. I've been using this setup for over a year with the same printed parts with no problems. Very rigid.

Follow the 3D systems instructions for removing an old hotend:
http://www.3dsystems.com/shop/support/legacy/manuals

Required hardware:
3 x M3 x 15mm SHCS
3 x m3 nylon lock nuts
3 x m3 washers (I super glued the washers to the printed mount to make it easier to screw on).

I opted for re-using the tiny Hotend PCB board (made it easier for disconnecting and servicing the hotends). Re-soldering the hotend to the PCB board was a huge pain though.

The 100k ohm Thermistor the comes with the E3D won’t work with the stock 3D touch board.
I purchased a half-dozen 200k ohm thermistors from Mouser Electronics (super cheap).
http://ca.mouser.com/ProductDetail/Semitec/204GT-2/?qs=%2fha2pyFaduiQiQmymLPXOWNnX3SMQrY3ZQhjlQOT21s%3d
Due to how fast the e3d hotend heats up it may overshoot during heating but it doesn’t seem to bother print quality much.

There’s a google group discussion on this very topic for more info:
https://groups.google.com/forum/#!topic/cubex-3d-printing/XfibDe2kkbU%5B101-125%5D

Caution: May change how high the nozzle sits when reassembled. Z-offset will need to be re-set otherwise the nozzle may crash into the bed.
-I recommend setting the z-offset to something like 12mm away from the nozzle before disassembling

Printer:

Modified BFB 3D Touch

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.25

Infill:

33%

Notes:

ColorFABB Co-polyester
Light sanding to make the groove mount slide through the opening depending on printer settings.

The original design caused the batteries to jam and not exit the box on the ramp. I solved this by adding a single ramp to the cover.

Only AA version for the time being. While still work in progress, this is the first working prototype which does the job quite well so far. Print face down so it doesn't need any supports. Including .c4d file.

comments.text: I have tried to print your design and stuck failure with the initial print only because I forgot that the flooring on my build plate does not like prints that have no raft . The buildtak is really good as I have been able to do at least 200 prints without actually changing the sheet. I was using the flashforge print sheets prior but found that when you change the sheet that you needed to use rubbing alcohol to remove the glue residue that was left. With this new improved buildtak when you replace the sheet there is hardly any glue to clean off. So with a raft in place I am able to print quite successfully but have to use a dremel to clean up the project after the print. Using adoniram's ramp and your casing im finding that his ramp is marginally shorter and does not fit your housing. One side clicks in perfectly and the bottom of the model also clicks into the responding groove but the other side is out by about 2-3mm .
comments.author: andmerr

comments.text: I tried it and it works flawlessly without glue. It just clips together and the batteries don't get stuck. Maybe in your case it's more of a printer issue.

I have managed to print the inner piece quiet well thanks , and after 8 hrs it came out really well after turning it on its side. His design was errored  for the casing and after numerous attempts have now forgone trying to print his design and now I to agree with  wschadow on how did his design go anywhere unless the company who bought it from him tweaked it for him......

comments.text: Alright, let me know how it turned out for you and if there's something that needs to be tweaked. Just make sure to print it face down, so with the A facing the print plate, otherwise it will need way too many supports and not print nicely.
Hm, good idea but have you tried it? My guess would be that the second layer of batteries gets stuck. I think that a ramp is needed for every layer of batteries.
comments.author: wschadow

comments.text: Yes I have tried and currently use it at home. It has been working well so far, even when stacking the batteries higher than the actual box. The first designs had the exact problem you mentioned, but the trick is the right gap between the ramp of the cover and the actual ramp for the exit. The only problem i had so far was that the batteries might stack below the cover, but that only ever happened when actively shaking the box. I could make a video and post that, but I'd rather have people try it for themselves and let me know if it works for them :-)

Simple filament cleaner or wiper that mounts to a 2020 extrusion frame.
Print with the bolt and top standing up and body on it's side without supports!!

You can use what ever , foam cloth, I've even used rolled up paper towel. Just make sure it's not over tight so the filament can pull through easy.

Many will say it's not needed, and I used to think so. but after having nozzle issues a few times in the last month I decided to try, hey it doesn't hurt anything. Well since install no clogs and filament seems to be smoother flowing. Hey we all don't live in hermetically sealed clean rooms, we live in the real world with dust and such in the air.

Head pivots. thread bolt in fully. designed so the threads on the bolt and the head actually go past each other and (in theory) don't come undone as it pivots. but using an hex Key you can get it back apart if for some reason need be.

Working on my Kossel can sometimes be frustrating, especially when I want to adjust the bed height and leveling at the beginning of a print, after downloading and printing every bed leveler / mount design that I could find and after none of them working I finally decided to design my own in Tinker Cad.

UPDATE: This design is depreciated, it allowed for too much bed movement which caused layer misalignment in larger prints, I designed a more stable / simplified version, check out at: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2092046

It's made up of 4 parts, the thumb screw, the mount base, the shafted bed mount and the top clip to lock the bed into place. You will need 3x M3x30 scews, 3x Springs and 3x M3 nuts as well as a T-slot nut and M3 screw to mount it to your 20x20 extrusion.

You may need to adjust your manual_z_home_pos setting in your firmware.

Printing in wood filament creates a nice feel to the thumb screw!

I used some of the design from WAIT24s KOSSEL ADJUSTER but ended up redesigning the whole thing so that it works better: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1407446

I used the nut hole from joecarpitas Spring Bed Leveling System (Kossel Clear, OpenBeam Printers) http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1056185 I decided after using his thumb screw, that it was too sharp and I re-designed it with rounded nubs.

Let me know if you like it. I have a few other designs that I am working on for adjustable bed mounts that I will release after testing.

print_settings.Printer:: Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

description.text:
Ok this is not a design or software, but rather a tutorial. The STL file is just a placeholder; do not download.

Cura (I'm using v2.3.1 for Mac) has a powerful yet less known feature: turning any photo into a lithophane. There are customizers available but Cura is simply more convenient, more flexible, and better quality.

1-Choose your favorite photo in jpg, bmp or png. The best ones are high contrast, simple contour ones. Basically, any photo that looks good in black and white will look good as a lithophane.

2-Open Cura and simply drag and drop the photo file into the window. A setting window will pop up. Set it up as below:

Height (thickest height): 2-4mm; the higher the darker black and better contrast, but more than 4mm and the dark region loses shades. Use a lower height for a life photo, but a higher one for an artistic photo like my example.

Base (thinnest height): 0.2-0.8mm; the higher the stronger lithophane, but the less bright light region and worse contrast.

Width and depth: the size of the lithophane so choose whatever that fits your need. On a Wanhao i3 I print 180mm longer edge because the bed is 200mm x 200mm.

Choose "Darker is higher".

Smoothing: drag to far left, then increase it in the slightest manner possible. No smoothing looks horrible, but anything more than the slightest smoothing blurs the image.

3-Print in white or any light or neutral color. Translucent filaments don't look good. Some key print settings are below:

Layer height: as low as possible to achieve the highest detail level. The Wanhao i3 z step size is 0.04mm so I recommend 0.04mm or 0.08mm, and no more than 0.2mm.

Initial layer height: use something that's no more than 1/2 of the base height in the import setting. This is to make sure there are at least a few bottom layers and the weaving doesn't show.

Infill density: 100% to print the lithophane solid.

Wall count: 1, because there is no strength concern. Similarly top layers = 0 and bottom layers = 999999 (they are only meaningful with hollow interiors).

4-Wait for print to finish, remove carefully (because it may be fragile; I cool my glass bed so it peels off easily), hold to light, and prepare to be wowed! The bumpy side should be facing you otherwise the image will look blurred.

Enjoy! This makes the best gifts for friends at almost no cost. Comments about settings to improve quality are welcome!

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.04mm or as low as possible

Infill:

100%

comments.text:
First I'd like to thank you for the awesome information. Exactly what I've been searching for. Secondly I hear some people talking about printing these upright on their edge with a brim or raft. Why would anyone print them this way! I just printed the Disney Princess one for my Granddaughter and printed it flat and it came out amazing!
Just a curious question :)
comments.author: Magikmerlin

comments.text: I don't think vertical printing, even if possible, has any advantage. In fact it would lead to overhang which may be difficult, let alone the adhesion issue. Flat printing is fast, easy, and yield consistently good outcomes. Why bother with the tricky way?
comments.author: Magikmerlin

comments.text: Vertical printing is actually the best way to print lithophanes. it gives the highest resolution for the greyscale. it's not tricky at all, i print them at  100 microns 100%infill no brim. a little glue stick if you have bed adhesion issues.
comments.author: icefox1983

comments.text: I tried one. The greyscale is indeed smooth. However horizontal lines are quite visible especially on the tall part. I print large lithophanes, nearly 200mm tall when vertical, and top flex is unavoidable. The other downside of vertical printing is that even the thinnest part has to be at least 0.4mm (my nozzle diameter) which limits contrast. All in all I think that vertical printing may be ok or even better for small sizes, but for large sizes flat is still the way to go.
comments.author: thecanadianlegend

comments.text: Hmmm great point about greyscale. You won't have the layering issue anymore! Although strength is a weakness (the lithophane will easily snap in the middle). Very interesting. I need to check it out.

author: najotarantula

title: Improved MakerBot Clock
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
UPDATE Jan., 7th, 2017

The printed clock works just fine - if not even better - without the washer, so don't bother...

UPDATE

Well since I hated the fact, that I originally had to print the clock's face upright at the same time with the base plate anyway, I decided to fix this nonsense, too. Therefore the "Improved Gears and Hands for MakerBot Clock" thing, is the Improved MakerBot Clock now, i.e. I have added the base, face and washer as individual .stl files. The washer is just the 0.5mm part of the original face plate, that is supposed to put some pressure on the gears to keep them in place. While I haven't tested this thoroughly, I don't see, why it shouldn't work as a separate part.

Release notes
After printing http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:299164 I was somewhat underwhelmed to find out that the original hands are not connected to the gears in a secure way (they just slip on), i.e. once you apply just the tiniest amout of real force while tuning the minute hand or any of the gears jam, the hands start detaching really quick.

My quick and dirty solution: hands and gears have dodecagonal profiles now. Hands and gears cannot rotate independently anymore and the transfer of force from the minute hand to the gears is improved. (Printed and tested.)

remixed_from.author: AzzA
remixed_from.title: Z braces for Wanhao Duplicator i3, Cocoon Create, Maker Select, and Malyan M150 i3 3D printers.

remixed_from.author: AzzA
remixed_from.title: Z Extensions for Wanhao Duplicator i3, Cocoon Create, and Maker Select

title: Back or Front Z Brace and Z Extensions (Z-Kit)

description.text:
I have been using both the Z-Braces and Z-Extensions from AzzA for sometime. They did the job needed at hand. My only problem was that the threaded rod got in my way. So the solution was to find some Z-braces that would not attach to the front. I simply could not find a set that did not use the front for the threaded rods. Not only that I was using some dampeners made to fit AzzA Z-braces. So I made my own braces that would still allow me to use the dampeners.
My solution was to just combine both things into one. This Z-Brace attaches to the side Z -Extensions rather than the front. This allows people the option to place the Z-braces on the front or the back. I only have a wanhao i3 v2 so I cannot say if this will work with other printers.
Thing to note is that there is not enough space to use the nut covers on the extension parts. You can see that in the pictures. You can see more by watching our video https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_dEAQhl3Z5w

The feet shown in the pictures can be found through the thingiverse links below.
First up is The noise-vibration-canceling spikes by teknikk7 http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1786023
Next is The dampeners by docpayce http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1572655

Printer:

Wanhao duplicator i3 v2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

100

Notes:

I recommend printing the parts with high infill and shells for strength. I printed my original set in abs and then acetone smoothed them for a nice look and strong part. I printed the second white set in pla since it has less flex than abs

Hardware needed for this mod

Things needed for the Z brace version

I used two 5/16" threaded rods however I think 8mm will also work. The length is around 17.5 inches or 444.5 mm, Of course this is a rough estimate that could be a little too long.
2 Locknut screws to use on the threaded rod within the bracing feet
6 normal screws to use on securing the threaded rod to the printed parts.
20 M3 by 10mm long screws or 16 if you don't plan on using the tower feet.
6 M6 bolts of you plan to use the version made for leveling feet
6 M6 nuts to use with the leveling feet models

Things needed only for the Zbrace with Extensions
Use all of the above as well, this includes the rod length estimate as I used that length with the extensions too.
4 m3 by 10mm long screws
4 m3 locknut screws or 8 m3 normal screws. These screws are used to raise and hold the top of the printer to the printed parts. You can use locknuts to get a firm secure hold, or jam two normal screws together for a similar effect.

Currently the files section may look to be a large mess so let me help list it out for everyone.
There are several sets of this mod in the files section this includes sets such as leveling feet, non leveling feet, Z brace and extension, and just Z brace

NON Leveling feet set file names:
Non_Brace_leg_1.stl
Non_Brace_leg_2.stl
Brace_leg_1.stl
Brace_leg_2.stl

Leveling feet set file names:
Nonbraceleg1_leveling_feet.stl
Nonbraceleg2_leveling_feet.stl
Braceleg1leveling_feet.stl
Braceleg2leveling_feet.stl

Z brace with extension set file names:
Extension1.stl For right side
Extension2.stl For left side
Zkit_scrapper_holder1.stl For right side

Z brace only set file names:
ZBraceTopRSide_scrapper_holder.stl
ZBraceTopLSide_scrapper_holder.stl
ZBraceTopRSide.stl
ZBraceTopLSide.stl

Added an edit section to clear up the summary section.

Edit: 6/5/17 This has been sitting on my computer for a while. I only recently had time to finally get them printed out and had pictures taken. For anyone wanting only a Zbrace and not also extensions this is for you. These new parts screw into the two original side screw holes. This actually makes the Zbrace install much more easy, in that you are only unscrewing the sides and leaving the front screws in place. They are properly labeled and I have ran them all through the online netfabb. With that done I am considering this thing finished.
Edit: 2/8/17 I have now remixed the scraper holder z extension from azza into a z kit part. The right side when facing front is the side that part goes on.
Edit:1/27/17 I uploaded a few pictures of the new feet on my printer.
Edit:1/23/17 My first upload of a set of parts that include leveling feet, you can see my quick update video here https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uC1peJXi7qE I ran all the stl files trough netfabb just in case.
Edit:1/18/17 I just uploaded another new leg test and some pictures of it. I know its slow progress, however leg tests result in less filament waste and help in refinement.
Edit:1/13/17 I added a different stl file for testing if the nut will snugly fit.
Edit:1/11/17 I added a new stl, this file is a small test to see if the m6 nut for leveling feet will snugly fit. I printed my parts above in abs and this test print in PLA.
Edit: 1/9/17 Simply changed the thing to a work in progress since I plan to try and add a leveling feet option.
Edit: 1/4/17 Ran all the stl files through Netfabb, if you have any issues let me know.

title: Updated Anet A6  A8 Z Axis motor hold down mounts (4 versions)

description.text:
UPDATE 14th Feb 2016. Updated to include 2 versions for the A6 and two for the taller frame of the A8. The two versions are one with the step and one without the step (For side mounting. See the pictures. Thanks to Draxan for details of issues with the A8.

Designed to stop flexing in the Anet A6 and A8 motor mounts. Designed to be screwed to a base. Personally I think these reprap printers need securing to a solid base.

Yes I know it looks like a big number one. This will fit if the Z-axis coupler has been installed correctly. I.e. only 5mm on the motor spindle in in the coupler.

description.text: Here is an easy belt tensioner I designed that helped quiet my bed resonance. I removed the belt springs and had this installed in a few minutes. In a departure from the metric sizes, I decided to go with a #8-32 x 1 1/4" hex socket cap head screw and an 11/32" nylon stop nut as my tensioner screw. It is just a little bigger than an M4 of the same type. It has proven to work beautifully. The slide is a perfect fit and incorporates angled guides to prevent pop out.

description.text:
UPDATE 30-5-17
Added Anet A8 version with 4 screw holes in the correct location

These mounts change the way your gantry attaches to the z axis.. in fact its not actually attached at all!! and that is why this works
Most Z banding is caused by bent/miss aligned lead screws/threaded rod by removing the gantry from the z axis and using gravity to hold it in place(which is MORE than enough) you are disconnecting the gantry in the X and Y plane. this means the threads/lead screws are free to oscillate back and forward (and left to right) without imparting that oscillation into the gantry and there for into your print. Simple but it works

The files attached are for 3 hole z axis nut
V2 uses a 4mm piece of PTFE tubing/rod to reduce friction (see pics)

as i understand a lot of people have 4 hole nuts or a hex nut as the lead nut i have (as always) included the SketchUp file so you may edit it to your hearts content.
This was designed in sketchup.

title: Voodoo System - Customizable Mocap, Simple Construction

description.text: The Voodoo System is a simple arduino based method to control servos in a direct way with RobotGeek Rotation Knobs, Buttons, and FSR, and can be laid out to match any robot you've built! You'll need 20mm and 10mm long M3 Bolts to build it. Bolts will thread into the plastic. Shown as an example is the layout for controlling a RobotGeek Snapper Arm. You can follow through some lessons using the code HERE.

comments.text: So I got that code uploaded onto the arm but it's real twitchy in some joints, anyway to fix that ?
comments.author: Rosellb2

comments.text: If you're using the snapper extensions, not really anything can be done about that. Without the extensions it should be less twitchy, but this whole system is in testing, and the code for it is far from perfect. To get rid of the twitching, you'd have to add some sort of averaging into the code beyond mapping, so that it doesn't try to update the position when only a fraction of degrees has been moved.
comments.author: Rosellb2

comments.text: How come your robot didn't twitch when with the extensions? Do you have any premade-available resource that I can use? I'm not much of a coder/programmer
comments.author: robotgeek

comments.text: It did twitch, so guessing yours is just twitching worse? Nothing premade beyond the code StarTrashElectronics provided you, you'll have to do it yourself if you want something that wasn't already provided any time soon.
comments.author: Rosellb2

comments.text: Hey, so do I need the the buttons and fsr if I want to control my robot arm with knobs
comments.author: Rosellb2

comments.text: Nope! If you're not using an FSR or a button to control any part of the arm, no need to make those parts.
comments.author: Rosellb2

comments.text: Also, are there instructions to put this thing together? I know I'll have to match knobs with corresponding servos but I'm I supposed to follow the order of each individual file when putting this thing together??
comments.author: robotgeek

comments.text: No instructions yet. The idea is to sandwich the RobotGeek Rotation Knob between the Bottom and Top pieces, hold it together with 2 x M3x10 bolts through the bottom, Remove the knob from the potentiometer and press fit the Voodoo Arm (short or long) onto the potentiometer splines. The 4 unpopulated holes around the circle are used to attach the parts together using 4 x M3x20 bolts. One of the big things about the system is that it can be arranged in many ways, not just as a robot arm. I'll get instructions out as soon as possible, but it might take a while.
comments.author: Rosellb2

description.text:
This thing was inspired from my Bearing-less fidget spinner. Check out that thing if you haven’t already! http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1960183

I wanted to make something really interesting and complex, yet at the same time be something that I like to print. So, after about 4 1/2 hours of designing, I came up with the cube in-a cube spinner! I like to call it the Cubical spinner! The first, and best spinner for mathematical, physics-ical, and CAD-ing nerds! It is not the easiest print, whereas it requires multiple supports, and a good layer height to print optimally. But once you overcome printing, you will have the coolest fidget-er in the block!

Robo 3D

R1 ABS + PLA Model

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

Infill:

10-100%

Notes:

Use supports from the BASE! if you use supports everywhere, it will probably screw up the holes from which the smaller cube spins... Unless you are lucky enough to own a printer with water soluble support. (looking at you, Ultimaker 3 owners...)

Remove supports CAREFULLY! Then, if your inside cube is fused, just gently turn the rods from either side of the cube, or the disks on the outside of it. It should break free and spin fine.

description.text:
This is a small thing to screw your selfie stick on a bottle ...
nice to take a picture of the entire family, after a nice evening.

This can replace a tripod , but takes no room in a bag and can remain screwed to your selfie stick ...
Can ' t be cheaper ...

Note: it could also be usefull if you use my selfie stick stabilizer (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2017905)

Thanks to mike_mattala for his great openscad file which i used to gneerate the 1/4 inch screw.

Be sure to print the screw with at least 70% infill.
Do not let it cooll down : immediately screw it afer the ens of the print, so that it takes the correct form.

2 small screws are needed to maitain he screw on the bottle cap.

Disclaimer : be carefull : test the stability before you leave your phone attached to a bottle, and ensure no one is playing with a ball around ! . I am not respopnsible for any usage right or wrong that you plan to have with that little thing.

K8200 extruders custom fishbone gears . New gear ratio is 9/47 Notice If you change these gears you need to calibrate your extruder stepper motor becouse gear ratio changes little.

  • Use this tutorial
    http://www.instructables.com/id/How-to-calibrate-the-Extruder-on-your-3d-Printer/?ALLSTEPS

    • yes it's made for solid doodle but basics are the same. Upate 7: Size problems is fixed now. Thanks to balthazar for testing the gears.
    I uploaded all new files these are untested with printer, but they are tested in 3d program. Update 6: Uploaded design without "k8200" text for those who like it more without text. Update 5: New V3 version uploaded. minor fixes. now 20% smaller so it fits better to k8200 extruder. Update 4: Finally fixed problems. Fully working teeths. Update 3: Majore flaws in teeth dimension. Fix coming soon.
    It wasnt good idea to upload before testing. Sorry for inconvience. Update 2: Uploaded fully working model of version 2.1 Update: I found way too many holes in big_gear so i deleted it and i will upload when i get it fixed.

Be sure to download correct version of the gears. There is couple different models.

  • No text only hexagons

  • K8200 text and hexagons

  • 1.5mm smaller bolt head for all designs

description.text:
This is an extension for the Learning Blade Haiti Orphanage Mission Challenge

Using the fully 3D printable Earthquake Shaker Table students will be able to test their structure designs for the Construction Response Activity.

Notes:

Bottom and Top should be printed at 10 - 15% percent infill / with 2 walls.

The springs in the video were printed at the same setting, but if you want stiffer or weaker springs you change your print settings accordingly.
NGSS
<iframe allowfullscreen="None" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/7XwgHYBUndw" ></iframe>

The fully 3D printable Earthquake Shaker table is to be used for testing student designs for earthquake resistant buildings. 
When students are testing their designs on the shaker table, have students tape their designs to the top so that it is anchored to it. There are

author: davidgonber

title: TurboPi  (Raspberry Pi 2 and 3 case)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Another Raspberry Pi case:)

Super cool case for raspberry pi. It was all snap together for me. There is mounting holes and mounts if you want to pull it all together with (4) 3mm x 8mm screws.

Installation is simple, place the cover upside down just as modeled. Place the IO section of the board in first and make sure it is all the way forward. You can double check this making sure the IO pins are lining up with the pattern of slots. Once that side is installed you can gently press down on the hdmi/power side of the board. Once it is level you can gently compress it into the cover. Should get a small snap. The bottom also snaps into the 4 corners and along the notches. Add some bump-ons on the bottom to reduce sliding and add airflow.

I created slots for the IO port pins to stick out through the case, My goal here was to make it so if anyone wanted to use those ports you could just snip or file all the dividers as they need to be there for support during printing anyway.

Also I think there is a good chance if you don't use the fins you can feed the camera cable in through the slots. Not 100% sure on this as I don't use the camera port but there should be just enough room. I suppose you could just remove the front fin to access this port as well. The fins are made to be pressure fit so if you are having trouble with them being loose or too tight just change the thickness of the fin to suit your needs. You should have to force them in so they stay in place.

I did get a little droop in the main body where the fins go but hard to see once the fins are installed.

As always I want to see those makes!

1/10/17 - I noticed after my 3rd print of this I am getting a little binding above the cable attachment area between the hdmi/audio cord. I will update this soon but just so you know I will tweak this. I also plan on relieving out the cover along the base for the IO plugs as well. That seems to be binding very slightly. I will update in the next couple days but still a sweet case as is.

This has been updated and cleaned up.

Printer:

Monoprice Dual ext

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

20
Might need to remove a few droops from the center recess.

My Mom likes gardening and flowers, so for her birthday, I printed a full size flower pot.  My machine isn\'t yet very fast, so it took more than 24 hours, but the result was quite nice.
This pot doubles as a science experiment: since I printed in PLA, the pot just might decompose.  It will be fun to find out whether it does and how quickly.
The design is probably too big for a Makerbot, but you can scale it with OpenSCAD.

Print the pot and the base.  The pot fits nicely in the base.  Make sure the base is waterproof.
I wouldn\'t recommend growing food in the pot unless you know the plastic is safe for food.

description.text:
Having bought a airsoft M4 I found that my handguard and outer barrel were quite wobbly, to fix I needed just to tighten down my delta ring.

But to do that you would need an armorers wrench which are not that easy to obtain where I live, and getting it done with a normal wrench or screwdrivers on a brand new replica was not an option.

So after some measurements I designed this and made it to fit a normal sized M4/AR15 delta ring.

It also includes a small hole to hang it on your tool rack or take it with you on a chain on the field.

description.text: Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:58001 Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=58001
Filament holder

A customizable box with a sliding top with a small catch. I'd love to see your prints of this if you make one! V2 includes now includes optional dividers. Check the customizer to add more (or less) dividers. The stl will create a box that holds 4 oblong pills. Hit the customizer to adjust the dimensions.

Customize! Print! Clean up!
  • There is a small slit on the underside of the lid that needs to be cleaned up to make sliding the lid open a bit easier.
  • It may be a good idea to sand the lid edges just a bit if the fit is too snug.
    • Use!
  • A bit of folded paper towel or toilet tissue in the bottom of the box helps keep the pills from rattling around and turning to dust.
    • Be conscious of the overhang angle on the lid. The .scad file will output the angle in OpenSCAD. An angle < 45 is probably a good idea.

Prints shown are right after printing and finished, acetone smoothed item. There is no supports built into the model, I let my printing software add these in during slicing.

remixed_from.title: XYZ da Vinci 1.0 Pro E3D V6 Drop-In Cartridge Mount

title: XYZ da Vinci 1.0 Pro E3D V6 Drop-In Cartridge Mount - Enhanced Cooling

description.text:
This is a somewhat hacked-up re-mix of the body of bdwalker1's "XYZ da Vinci 1.0 Pro E3D V6 Drop-In Cartridge Mount" to make it hopefully cool the E3D hotend better.

I closed some gaps that let cooling air escape where it shouldn't, opened up the 'channel' to let more air flow to the bottom, and partially blocked the top part of the heatsink to hopefully re-direct the air primarily to the bottom of the heatsink, where it's critical.

V2 revision created

This version should be printable without supports, given a low enough layer height (0.2mm)

*NOTE* These are thus far UNTESTED by me as I don't have my DaVinci modded at this time, but it should cool the hotend properly and prevent heat creep, which causes clogging. See bdwalker1's thing for the instructions and clamp and fan shroud: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1328848

Printer:

Any

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm height / 0.mm nozzle

Infill:

15% Honeycomb

Notes:

See bdwalker1's thing for the instructions and clamp and fan shroud:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1328848

comments.text: I have no problem at all printing this with no supports. My Da Vinci 1.0a is able to bridge this just fine.
comments.author: larryparamedic

comments.text: Jeff, I see the way you modified the air channel on my design to possibly better cool the lower fins of the heatsink. I can see the potential advantage, but I also see a minor disadvantage in that I don't see how this modified design could be printed without supports. I have not had any heat creep problems with my current design, but if I experience any I may have to give this design a try.

comments.text: Hi bdwalker1,

comments.text: Jeff, You don't sound like a jerk at all. I very much appreciate that you made this remix to help someone in the community that was experiencing an issue.

description.text: Ausstechform für Mutzenmandeln / Mutzen.

When strapping GoPros to our quads using wedge-style mounts, whether they be printed foam or carbon fiber based, we're leaving the cameras totally unprotected. This little hat slides on your battery strap and fits over the top of the camera, offering a fairly minimalistic and light weight solution to that problem. It's obviously not going to protect the lens in the event of a head-on collision, but I got sick of watching the top lip of my camera be slowly eaten away by concrete every time I crashed.

Print face-down without supports.

9/11/17 - Just realized I'd never added the other version, the one that I've actually used since day one, that removes the bit of the mount from the camera's view. Added that file named Hyphy_Hat_v2

title: Fiat Nuova 500 simplified cnc/laser
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The Fiat Nuova Cinquecento (500) was built from 1957 through 1975. The 500 derives from the cubic capacity and the first version had 13,5 horse power which propelled the vehicle to a maximum speed of a blazing 50 miles per hour. Probably easy fast enough for traffic jam in Rome.

My build was done on a desktop cnc-machine by Stepcraft using a spiral-toothed 1.2 mm flute. I used 6 mm beech plywood and 6 mm beech rods for the the axles. I added a little bit of grease to improve the rotation, washers give the tires (darkened with wood stained) a proper displacement.

A laser cutter might be a good alternative tool to build this model. Consider that some sophisticated parts need a certain size and/or material to be strong enough.

Visit https://www.zenziwerken.de/en/Spielsachen for more toy designs.

Keep in mind, that the stl is for viewing purpose only. Do not print this design on a 3d-printer!

The plastic breaks on the Hoda pilot seats and finding a repalcement part is hard and expensive. rebuilding them is a pain. So... A 3D printed solution it was!! I made this for my 2003 honda Pilot and they have worked great. a cover for the seat to make it look more finished will be the next item.

Print two, one for each cable. I used 45% infill on mine with .2mm layer height and 3 outer walls.

Let me know if it works for you!

comments.text: This worked great. I haven't been able to lay the seats flat in years.  Replacement parts were over $300 because you have to buy complete package with cables. Thanks so much for sharing this design!

print_settings.Notes:: You can double-sided tape them to anything you might want to tilt back a bit.

description.text:
It's a simple pair of wedge legs for my WR-282 radio box. They let me see the front panel easier.

After years of looking for (and rejecting) Internet radio boxes, I finally snagged a good one. Meets all of my feature desires and then some - the only deficiency is that when sitting on a counter-top, its face is not at a user-friendly angle.

3D printing to the rescue.

This pair of legs simply tilts the unit back so it's easier to interact with it. The legs are held in place with some double-sided tape.

Not expecting that many people will have the same WR-282 internet radio as I do, but perhaps these legs will be useful for something you do have. Maybe they can be the start of something you need with a remix. So I've shared here for you to play with them. :)

Printer:

MP Select Mini

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

15%

Notes:

Seems to accommodate a low fill ratio very nicely. Nothing fancy required.

You can double-sided tape them to anything you might want to tilt back a bit.

title: Strain wave gear with timing belt

description.text:
Just a proof of concept that I said I'd make available for others - no guarantee that the details below are correct or the design will work for you.

Here's the original and a guide to assembly: https://youtu.be/AzreNQiTvQE

You need an M8 bolt at least 40mm long, 4 M8 washers and an M8 nut. Two 608 "skateboard" bearings are used in the centre of the gear. You also need a pair of 13mm OD and 4mm ID bearings for the wave generator and a couple of M4x12mm screws - preferably pozi head to keep the head as low profile as possible - normal socket head M4 will interfere. Finally, you need an HTD 3mm pitch, 270mm long continuous (closed loop) timing belt.

description.text:
Yet another bloody Fidget Spinner from me!
This one uses the same 40gram golf putter weights as the previous incarnations...
See ebay for details.. https://goo.gl/nGLR5H
Very nice with a full Zirconium ceramic centre bearing.. See the others spinners from me for suitable "centre mushrooms" for your bearings..

Malyan M150

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm or 0.1mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

I used PET-G, like I always do!
60C bed
258C hot end
80mm / sec

Set the resolution and infill to what you normally use.. I have bulk PET-G, so use 100%!
It can be tight to get the weights in.. If it's really tight, resize, and try again...
Hopefully MY mistakes will be your fixes!

comments.text: Great work man! I'm new to this site, and I'm really interested in this spinner. Really wanted to get the body made. Few questions,
comments.author: VSMOTO

comments.text:
I used a standard 608 skate bearing just for testing the design, then I have used standard 608 and 627 Ceramic and Ceramic Hybrids..
I have had over 5 minute spins with the full ceramic option..
The tungsten weights are available on ebay in various options, from 5g all the way to 40g.. And they come with the fitting wrench.. You will need this to screw them in!
It was printed on my Malyan M150 (Wanhao i3 clone) in PET-G.. I have not tried PLA, as I don't have any!
Re altering the file, no changes should be needed if you use PET-G, just print away using the settings shown in the project description..
I can't say about other filaments as I don't use them.. Although I do have some wood filament that I plan on trying soon.
comments.author: VSMOTO

comments.text:
Thank you so much for responding!
Just a few more questions, I'm actually getting this made through materialize, in different materials, steel and alumide. So how did you put your bearings in? Is it a press fitting? What about buttons? I'm guessing any 608 bearing button should do fine as well? I have a 608 bearing laying around which I'll try, but I'm more interesting in putting a r188 bearing (608 adapter)
https://fidgethq.com/collections/fidget-spinners/products/kong-3-in-1-fidget-spinner-608-adaptor-with-r188-removable-bearing
comments.author: pshax

comments.text:
Never heard of Materialize, but I'll have a lookie at them later..
re the bearings, I use standard 22mm dia bearings, but my preference is for full Zirconium ceramic.. Not cheap, but they do spin for ages!
The bearing is a tightish press fit, so if you are making one from steel, you'll need to enlarge the hole a bit, and glue the bearing in..
The weights have a threaded portion, so will also need the holes enlarging, and epoxying in place.. The weights cut their own thread in the PET-G I made the original from.. The centre mushrooms are a press fit, with an M3 buttonhead screw holding the two halves tightly together ..
I'd like to see a pic of the steel version.. maybe I'll tweak the design and get one done myself! :-)
comments.author: VSMOTO

comments.text: Haha, I already ordered using that stock design, thought that it would have the same sizes across these different materials. I unfortunately have no idea how to enlarge the designs. What you call mushrooms, I guess I call buttons. So any standard buttons available for these buttons should work and screw together I'm assuming.
comments.author: pshax

comments.text:
The Mushrooms are the centre buttons... Just make the size that fits the central hole...
The hole sizes will be constant across the different materials, but plastics will allow a simpler interference fit than sintered steel!!
It shouldn't take too long with a Dremel and a sanding drum to enlarge the holes in the steel frame...
comments.author: VSMOTO

comments.text:
Thank you! I think my final question is, what kind of glue would I need? Would this work?
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B000FP8EUS/ref=ox_sc_sfl_title_2?ie=UTF8&psc=1&smid=ATVPDKIKX0DER
comments.author: pshax

comments.text: It might work for metal to metal, but I'd go with 5 minute epoxy, as it has better gap filling, and way higher shear strength.. And you may find it's cheaper than thread adhesive, with more uses once you've used it on the spinner....
comments.author: VSMOTO

comments.text:
So something like this?
https://www.amazon.com/Loctite-Instant-0-47-Fluid-Syringe-1365868/dp/B0044F9KFI/ref=sr_1_8?ie=UTF8&qid=1492780914&sr=8-8&keywords=5+minute+epoxy
comments.author: pshax

comments.text:
That'll nicely do for metal to metal joints..
Just make damn sure the parts are aligned before the epoxy cures, as there is no easy way to "unglue" parts once it's gone off!
comments.author: VSMOTO

comments.text: I don't care too much about the tungsten weights being glued in, but lets say for the bearing itself, I wanted a tight enough seal and for perhaps future upgrades, wanted it to be removed. Do you still suggest epoxy?
comments.author: pshax

comments.text: The centre bearing could be "glued" in with silicone RTV.. But only use this with ceramic bearings, as the acetic acid released during curing could rot the bearing races...  Or find some electrical, non acetoxy grade sealant... Would also work with the tungsten weights..
comments.author: VSMOTO

author: pshax

print_settings.Notes:: Can be printed in PLA and ABS, although PLA has a better strenght to weight ratio.

description.text:
This is a new take on printing quadcopters. Most models take the standard frame setup of carbon plates with spacers inbetween and try to print that. This model streamlines and simplifies the frame. The frame is tight and robust.

The model consists of only three unique parts: a main body, a front arm and a rear arm. These are all mirrored for a total of six parts. All the parts are then bolted together using M4 bolts and nuts.

The frame is for a 300 size quad. The main body houses a 22x44x136mm battery tightly. The model is build around this battery, so printing it directly for any other battery might not fit. The electronics are glued on the sides of the body. A hollow space in front houses the FPV camera.
The motors are bolted on the end of the arms. The motors are tilted between 0 and 30 degrees. The arms are labeled with T00 - T30 for this. The cables run inside of the arms. The arms also protect the motors.

Printer:

Own design

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Infill:

20-100

Notes:

Can be printed in two runs on a square bed of 300x300mm. Main body has to be on the diagonal.

The main body does not need support. Print it with the side flat.
The arms might need it on the outside and underside. Be sure to clear the hollow inside of the arms of all support, this is very hard to clean out and it not necessary at all.

The infill and outside shell layers determine the weight and strength of the frame. One will be traded in for the other. A frame of 70-100% infill and 5 shells will be +-400g and thus rather heavy but it can handle a rather harsh drop. Remember that this is a big size quadcopter. Lowering to 2 shells and 20-50% infill will be a lot lighter but a high drop or two will bust it.

I printed them with two outer shells and 30% infill with a triangular pattern.

Can be printed in PLA and ABS, although PLA has a better strenght to weight ratio.

description.text:
3D printable open-action magazine release button for the AR-15 platform. This device prevents the magazine from being released, unless the action of the rifle has been opened. It has been designed for simplicity and affordability, at the cost of durability and performance.

This device is a single piece which is compatible with the mil-spec magazine release and spring, and requires no tools to install. The device noticeably protrudes from the side of the rifle to allow this ease of installation. The device may wiggle with no magazine attached, but will become securely fixed once a magazine is inserted and the action is closed.

Points of failure with this design and printing orientation is the peg which presses up against the upper receiver and the protrusion in the magazine release hole. The silver-lining to this is the device can be destroyed in an emergency and the remnants will function as a normal magazine release. The other drawback is the device can be overpressed, and the magazine release may become unaligned with its slot (see picture with my hand in it to see this demonstrated). This can be avoided by not overpressing, and resolved by simply realigning the magazine release.

Installation:

  1. Open action.
  2. Place magazine release spring and then this device in the magazine button hole, and hold.
  3. Place magazine release in left side of the receiver and screw into this device (it should tap itself).
  4. Ensure the device is fully pressed when installing, screw the magazine release as many times as your possibly can.

Printed in ABS and function tested with Gen 2 PMAG's and USGI magazines. Better durability can probably be attained with PETG/nylon, but the magazine release may not tap well.

Use at your own discretion.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm Layer Height

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Do not print in PLA, it will melt.

A stupid modular shower hanger thing I made, so that I can hang my Taotronics

  • Successfully printed using
    • PLA (210C, 70C hotbed)
    • 25% infill
  • The hook and adapter can be printed in different orientations; you decide
    what's best based on your printer and support preferences
  • I used Cura to slice this, and for the spacer, I needed to disable both "Combine everything" settings in Expert settings, as well as enable "Keep open faces". I assume this is because I messed up the model somehow, but I can't see where. All preview modes look fine except for Layers, which seems to add infill to the top, even though that should be a hole.

I've glued some of the parts together, which can be seen in the photos. This isn't strictly required of course, but the adapter plug I made for the taotronics probably needs to be glued onto either the speaker itself, or the spacer.

title: PLA Temperature Tower for the Da Vinci Pro and other machines
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
To know the best printing temperature for your PLA filament, you have to print yourself a temperature tower that shows you the characteristics of your filament at different temperatures.

This tower can help you, but make sure to set the printing temperatures in your slicer. I know this can be done in Simplify3D, but it might be that other slicers can do so as well.

The video here explains how to do it:
https://youtu.be/4VzoUXK36Fo

MAJOR UPDATE !!!!! 05-01-2017

I have uploaded the .3w file for this model that can be printed via XYZWare for Pro.
All the temperatures in this model are set, you don't have to do anything.
THIS IS ONLY FOR THE DA VINCI PRO 1.0

Update 10-01-2017

I have received some emails that the .3w files don't work on the 3-in-1 and on some models of the Pro 1. There is nothing I can change about this. In this case you can use the Simplify3D process file OR you have to set the temperatures your self.

comments.text:
Hi all,
I found out that the 3w wiles won't load.
This means that the tower is only useful if you have Simplify3D and you are able to set the temperatures.

title: Micro Quad Indoor Obstacle Course
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Create your own test of skill for indoor quadcopter flying. Print the parts for popular obstacles like knock down targets, the "hand of time", and various gates ... including the dreaded "mail slot" challenge.

Our little group gets together in a conference room and uses the Blade Inductrix to fly timed obstacle course runs setup on the tables in the room. Usually we set up 10 or so 'challenges' and do three timed rounds. Best course time and best total sum of three times wins bragging rights.

Example flight: https://goo.gl/photos/8ga9GRXRQvQa7grcA

Here is an example course:

  1. "Diamond of Death" Gate which has an opening of 15cm (6") wide by 15cm (6") tall or so. Use two square clip feet to hold it up.

  2. Tall 'pylon' 30cm (12") tall, which you must fly around (either direction) 360 degrees. Use
    circular clip base. You must NOT knock it over!

  3. 20cm (8") tall knock down target. You must knock it over, or push it off the table. Use diagonal clip base, plus base, square base or rectangular base - depending on how hard you want it to be to knock over.

  4. "Hand of Time" you must push the 'hand' around 360 degrees either direction. For extra fun, use a hand which is about 1/2 the width of the table and place the round base in middle of the table. Coming in and out of ground effect makes this a challenge.

  5. ...
  6. ...
  7. ...

  8. more knock down targets, pylons to circle, .etc.

  9. The "mail slot" challenge. Similar to first gate, but with a rectangular opening with the rectangle of foam taped to the top edge as a hinge. Currently using 16cm wide by 10cm opening.

  10. Land on top of a box. Box is about 30 x 30 x 30 cm or so. (1 foot square)

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

TAZ 5

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3mm layers

Infill:

50% or more

Notes:

I used ABS, but PLA or PETG should work fine.

Add some foam or foam board strips

Foam is 1/4" (6mm) fan fold foam sheet (or poster board)

If you need to alter the foam width or use cardboard, just edit the OpenSCAD file and change the constant for foam thickness.

Designed with OpenSCAD

My OpenSCAD design is included for your enjoyment.

author: Mr_Disintegrator

description.text: Anti Z-Wobbler para la Impresora 3D Maker T145.

Una vez impreso se debe desmontar la tapa de la T145, sacar la varilla roscada y poner el anti z como se ve en las fotografías. Con una tuerca para 8 mm en el hueco. Para que se quede fija yo la pegué con la Gotita, se puede empujar con un resorte o hacer el hueco menos alto.

Resultado final, con wobble y sin wobble...

comments.text: I think you might find that the wobble is due to the fact that the threaded rods have no machined end in the coupler. This means that they aren't precisely their quoted diameter. 8mm threaded rod is slightly less than 8mm. The aluminum coupler you have there is for linking machined rod, so your slightly undersized threaded rod is held off center.

In the Doctor Who episode "The Power of Three," millions of identical black cubes appeared across the world and laid dormant for a year before activating.  
This is a salt shaker inspired by that episode, in which the cubes started becoming so commonplace people started using them as paperweights.  Why not have a couple on your dining room table as salt and pepper shakers?  
The corners are blunted slightly as a perfect cube printed would be really sharp.  Safety first!  You may also have to reduce the lid in size very slightly (down to 99% worked for me) to get it to fit into the frame.

title: New pixel jig for Boscoyo strips

description.text:
Newly designed jig for installing bullet or square node pixels into Boscoyo mounting strips. Multiple pieces can be printed and combined end to end to make a longer jig if needed.

8/30/17--Added new jig to fit the new thicker heavy duty Boscoyo Strips

comments.text:
Hi, Mine measured right at about 16mm, so that means they printed right.. Phew!
What I see happening is that regardless of how hard I push, the rim around the hole puckers downward from the barb of the pixel because the gap from the shoulder of the channel to the rim of the hole is too wide, (so it seems). The pixel LED never hits the bottom of the channel, so that is not the issue. The flat face of the pixel body (I'm using the square pixels), stops on the strip which is on the shoulder that supports the strip, so no matter how hard you push, it can't go any farther down. What is happening is when that rim around the hole puckers downward, it does not snap back under the barbs that hold the pixel in place. It remains puckered just over 50% of the time.
When I added the spacers along the sides it changed the width of the channel to just over 13mm and it supports the rim around the hole much better and allows the barb to snap all the way thru.
Not sure it the strips flex more or the LED mold is different now a days or if there is another reason why they were not working. For me that simple little linear spacer worked really well. Wish I had thought of this sooner.. ha ha..
comments.author: plasmadrive

comments.text:
Im not sure why that is happening, maybe a variance in the pixels or in the strips themselves. One reason I redesigned the jig to begin with was because my previous one used steel pins to hold the strip in place using the small holes in the strips. What I quickly noticed was that some strips wouldnt go over the pins while some fit loosely on them. If you go to the red site(assume this is the same plasmadrive from there) and watch my video using this jig, you can hear each pixel snapping into place and im using very little effort to push them.
Also my pixels, the barbed section measures around 12.80mm, if i changed the dimensions of the jig to 13mm I think it would be too tight and could cause issues with any pixels that arent sitting perfectly straight..
Thanks for the feedback, ive sent out over 40 sets of these and this is the first time ive heard of any problems getting them into the strips.
comments.author: plasmadrive

comments.text:
Yes, it's me..I didn't realize it was you.. ha ha..
Your video clearly show them snapping.. Mine didn't do that at all.. not even once.. I think the material may be a bit softer now... That is all I can figure out..
comments.author: didjareally

comments.text:
Hi, I printed a few of these and after pushing about 1000 pixels I went back to do some soldering and some of the pixels popped out of the strips. Upon further investigation I found that >50% of them were not seated correctly. Turns out the inside channel is too wide.
My question is what is your intended internal width of the channel?
I wonder if my printer is off that much. I have never really calibrated it per se`
I cured the problem for future pixel pushing by creating .05" spacers and gluing them on each side of the internal channel. Unfortunately I caught it after I pushed the first 1000 and 2/3 of those are trapped by wire ties for extension.. so I have to fix them by hand.. My poor thumbs.. ha ha..
Anyway, thank you for the design and the files.. I really am interested in the intended dimension so I can see if that is truly my printer issue.
Thanks
comments.author: plasmadrive

comments.text: It was set to be 16mm on the model, my printed one measures just shy of that at 15.90mm.  I assume by the channel too wide you are meaning that it allows the strip to bow down as you are trying to push the pixel, therefore that hat of the pixel is hitting the base of the jig before snapping into the strip?  On mine the strip moves maybe a mm or 2, even after the pixel snaps into the strip I can push as hard as I want and it never touches the base.  I have added some pictures above that show the clearance around the pixel.
comments.author: plasmadrive

print_settings.Notes:: Recommend printing at 99% scale for a slightly tighter fit around a standard deck of cards. I rounded up in the design phase to account for non-standard cheaper decks.

description.text:
My family plays a lot of 3-13 which requires playing with many decks of cards. This becomes annoying with a card shorter tray since you constantly need to refill, or they all fall over. So after trying a few existing models that didn't work out, I decided to make my own.

This is a standard deck tray, commonly used for Canasta, but it's a bit taller. Feel free to scale it up even taller for your prints.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2 Extended

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.12mm

Infill:

25%

Notes:

Recommend printing at 99% scale for a slightly tighter fit around a standard deck of cards. I rounded up in the design phase to account for non-standard cheaper decks.

Autodesk 123D Design

123D is off to a good start. Needs a little help in the sketch tools and better snapping It's not very tolerant to mistakes when selecting edges - a "select sharp edges" like Blender has would be fantastic here. But otherwise it's pretty good. Took me six tries to get this model just right, but once I did, it came out really geometrically perfect.

title: Micro Quad Racing Gates
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Build your own indoor racing air gates or pylons. Just print out the base parts, one or more connectors, and buy some 1/2" pipe insulation from your local home improvement store.

You can use a string to keep the gate feet together. Optionally you can also tape them down using some painter's masking tape.

I've included the OpenSCAD file in case you need to adjust the dimensions for your pipe insulation.

I used colored duct tape to give them a bit of flair and make them easier to see when flying FPV.

Example FPV videos:
https://goo.gl/photos/Ztvv7cL7rKAUKwPk8
https://goo.gl/photos/LgNrdgLTeU6FtYQt9

author: Mr_Disintegrator

description.text: modified Jamesgao's case for a better fit and modified button cutout for better feel

Do you have multiple set of keys in your keychain? Do you want to bring with you your pen drive? Do you wish to carry anything you want with your keys? This is the modular keychain. You can build millions of adaptors to bring with your keys and attach it to the main element, the attachment mechanism is very simple, but reliable, and easy to build, as simple as a T extrusion.
You will need a long M4 screw and a nut, or (I think that is the best solution), one M4 screw plus a long female threaded tube.

Please, be careful, this is a WIP, any comments are welcome. When I can finish the main element, I want to build a better USB adaptor and a slimmer keychain to carry another set, as the work keys.

First, I measure my actual keychain, trying to achieve a flatter set of keys, rigid and linear, so it fits anywhere and doesn't hurt my trousers...
With that measures and the form's idea, I tryed different form options. Lastly, I created the modular mechanism, with the T extrusion.

description.text:
Visit my blog for more pictures: http://www.afdhalatifftan.com/

Summary:
-I printed this in Excelvan Coffee and Red ABS filaments
-I use E3D Volcano (clone) to speed up print time, so, each part takes less than 90 minutes to print.
-Designed in 123D Design.
-The box was intended to be mounted on top of the bike frame.
-Able to hold three 4S 8000mAh lipo and ten 18650 cells.
-Took almost 1kg of ABS plastic
-Parts are glued using acetone and super glue (parts named bracket)
-Printer used was Wanhao Duplicator i3 aka Di3
-Connections made by using XT60 and XT90 connectors
-DB25 was used as balancing port
-The box is secured in XYZ-axis
-The Z-axis was secured using Nut Job: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:193647
